resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Currently, {{ArrowReader.close()}} will close resources (VectorSchemaRoot and Dictionary Vectors) and also close the input ReadChannel, or InputStream for ArrowStreamReader.  Closing of the ReadChannel should be done by what ever created it because it might need to be reused.

If this not possible, an alternative could be to add a method {{ArrowReader.end()}} that will close resources but not the ReadChannel.  Then {{end()}} could be called instead of {{close()}}.
fields.summary: [Java] ArrowReader should not close the input ReadChannel

comments.body: Do you want this to go into 0.7.1? This patch could go in today if so cc [~siddteotia]
Yeah, that would be great.  The request came out of a Spark PR https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/19349 and might be another good reason to update to latest Arrow.  I can try to get this done soon.
OK, ARROW-1611 (https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1133) is the only other patch we wanted to go into 0.7.1. It would be great to get this done today so I can cut the release candidate

GitHub user BryanCutler opened a pull request:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138

    ARROW-1613: [Java] Removed closing of ReadChannel from ArrowReader.close()

    This change removes the closing of the input `ReadChannel` from `ArrowReader.close()` so it can be left up to the creator of the channel.  `ArrowReader.close()` will still release resources from `VectorSchemaRoot` and any Dictionary vectors read.  Also updated usage in tests to close input channels correctly.

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

    $ git pull https://github.com/BryanCutler/arrow java-ArrowRead-not-close-input-ARROW-1613

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

    This closes #1138
    
----
commit 7d95df94d99fe629f0f331a19fb315af7d7bb1f8
Author: Bryan Cutler <cutlerb@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-09-26T19:32:02Z

    Removed closing of ReadChannel from ArrowReader.close() and updated usage in tests to close things correctly

----

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    ping @siddharthteotia @icexelloss @elahrvivaz if you could please take a look and verify this change is ok.

Github user elahrvivaz commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    lgtm, thanks - we should maybe emphasize this change, as users will need to make sure to close input streams now.

Github user wesm commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    Are we comfortable calling this a bug? I wonder if this change might be too nuanced for a minor release

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    True.. I labeled it as a bug because it didn't seem like the correct behavior to me, but I can see it the other way too.  It's ok with me if you think it's better to hold off on this for a minor release.

Github user icexelloss commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I am not too sure about this change. In my impression reader object usually closes the resource associated with it, for instance, InputStreamReader.
    
    I will take a deeper look later today.

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I forgot that `ArrowWriter.close()` also closes the WriteChannel, so it probably wouldn't be good to change one and not the other.  Maybe it is best to add another method `ArrowReader.end()` that will close resources, but not the ReadChannel.  Does that sound preferable?

Github user wesm commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I think this issue bears more discussion, and I would like not to block 0.7.1 and proceed with the RC. I'm mindful of helping Spark move forward so if we need to do another point release before 0.8.0 (which should go out by end of October) that is OK with me.

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I agree not to block the release for this so we can discuss. There is a workaround also, so it's not preventing anything in Spark.  @wesm from what I can tell, C++ and Python reader/writers don't close the stream right?  Should we try to be consistent if it makes sense here?

Github user wesm commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    Right, they don't close the passed output stream

Github user siddharthteotia commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    So what is the protocol we are trying to enforce? Is it the following?
    
    user app -> ArrowReader.close()
    user app -> readchannel.close()
    
    user app -> ArrowWriter.close()
    user app -> writechannel.close()
    
    What are the scenarios that require callers to keep channels opened even after closing the ArrowReader / ArrowWriter?

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    The scenario is in Spark a socket is opened between the JVM and a Python worker process.  Then Arrow data is sent over the socket and when done, if the socket is left open, the Python worker can be reused which saves startup time. So I just need a convenient way to close resources without closing the stream.
    
    On one I think that Arrow doesn't own the stream, so should never close it.  On the other hand, for a `close()` method the user might expect the stream to be closed also.  Maybe someone else has some prior experience can confirm what the usual behavior is?

Github user siddharthteotia commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I am not sure of the potential impacts on downstream consumers (like Dremio and others) of Arrow.
    Is it just about explicitly closing the channel after closing the stream
    
    The way I look at close() operation is that it should typically release all resources. So the caller should consciously use this operation. It's counter intuitive to me that after close(), additional operation(s) is/are needed to release other resources (in this case it would be the channel)
    
    How about overriding the close() operation for specialized semantics for the scenarios @BryanCutler mentioned?
    
    Thoughts? cc @jacques-n

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    It sounds like this could possibly be too disruptive, so I will change to add an alternate `close(boolean closeReadChannel)` that can close resources without the input stream, and `close()` will keep the same behavior.

Github user jacques-n commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I don't think we use any of this code @siddharthteotia. Am I wrong?

Github user icexelloss commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    From an API point of view, I kind of prefer having something like `finish()` rather than `close()`
    
    The reason being `close()` have a pretty well defined semantics in most java io libraries and have a parameter to it might be weird. `finish()` kind of make sense because it (the reader) finishes reading.

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    Thanks @icexelloss.  I made it an alternative `close` because `ArrowWriter` has an `end()` and the meaning there is that writing is done and it is end-of-stream (for the stream format), but doesn't do anything with resources.  Here it is specifically to close resources so I think keeping the name `close` makes more sense and the original `close()` is still there which acts the same way.

Github user wesm commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    What's the state of this patch?

Github user BryanCutler commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    I still like the API how it is here. I've seen `close` methods with a bool to control closing of underlying connections elsewhere, but I'm not sure if there is a general standard.  @icexelloss if you feel strongly about having it be `finish()` or `end()` instead, I'm ok with that too.

Github user icexelloss commented on the issue:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
  
    Sorry for the late reply.
    
    I am OK with `close(boolean closeReadChannel)`

Issue resolved by pull request 1138
[https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138]

Github user asfgit closed the pull request at:

    https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/1138
